DataElement.preferredDefinition: The free-text field to describe the tumor antigen that the product was altered to recognize.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Product Alteration Recognition Tumor Antigen Performed
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A thing produced by or resulting from a process. EXAMPLE(S): drug, device. The FDA list of regulated products: animal and human drugs; therapeutic biologics; allergenics; cell, tissue and gene therapy products; blood components; blood derivative products; devices; and animal (pets and livestock) and human food/feed (medicated and un-medicated); cosmetics; pet treats; and dietary supplements._A change resulting in something that is different from the original._The act of seeing something as familiar._1. antigens that may be frequently associated with tumors or may be specifically found on tumor cells of the same origin (tumor specific); 2. tumor antigens may also be associated with replication and transformation by certain DNA tumor viruses, including adenoviruses and papovaviruses. Neoantigens. Any immunologically detectable marker whose presence or amount indicates the presence of a tumor._Executed and carried through to completion.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: The end result of a manufacturing process; anything that is produced.:A change resulting in something that is different from the original.

Concepts.definition: The end result of a manufacturing process; anything that is produced.
The act or process of modifying something.

Property.preferredDefinition: The act of seeing something as familiar.:1. antigens that may be frequently associated with tumors or may be specifically found on tumor cells of the same origin (tumor specific); 2. tumor antigens may also be associated with replication and transformation by certain DNA tumor viruses, including adenoviruses and papovaviruses. Neoantigens. Any immunologically detectable marker whose presence or amount indicates the presence of a tumor.:Executed and carried through to completion.

Concepts.definition: The act of seeing something as familiar.

1. antigens that may be frequently associated with tumors or may be specifically found on tumor cells of the same origin (tumor specific); 2. tumor antigens may also be associated with replication and transformation by certain DNA tumor viruses, including adenoviruses and papovaviruses. Neoantigens. Any immunologically detectable marker whose presence or amount indicates the presence of a tumor.
Executed and carried through to completion.
